SOLAR radiation penetrating the ozone hole over Antarctica may be damaging the base of the food chain that sustains virtually all wildlife in the region.

Dr. Sayed Z. El-Sayed of Texas A & M University and his colleagues report that certain wavelengths of ultraviolet radiation from the sun inhibit the growth of microscopic phytoplankton organisms found in Antarctic waters. Phytoplankton, which belong to the vegetable kingdom, use the process called photosynthesis to make their own food from carbon dioxide. Plankton are the main food of krill, which in turn are eaten by squid, fish and whales. Higher up the food chain, penguins, seals and winged birds depend on animals that subsist on plankton-eaters.

In experiments at Palmer Station in Antarctica, Dr. El-Sayed's group measured the effects of varying amounts of radiation on plankton reproduction and growth. The highest growth rates resulted when ultraviolet was completely filtered out of the sunlight reaching the microscopic plants. Increased ultraviolet exposure appeared to decrease photosynthesis by destroying the plant chlorophyll that catalyzes the reaction.

Plant and animal life are normally protected from the most hazardous forms of ultraviolet by a layer of ozone gas in the stratosphere, which blocks ultraviolet rays. But chlorofluorocarbon chemicals released into the atmosphere from spray cans, refrigerators and other sources have begun to destroy the ozone, scientists say. Huge seasonal gaps in the ozone layer have begun to appear over both poles, particularly over Antarctica. This year's ozone hole over the continent, which is growing rapidly, may prove to be the worst ever measured.
